results.title: Families: food and eating
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, George McQuilkin, Jane Treiman and James Kennedy
results.brief_description: Shows how the three families introduced in “Families: alike and different” obtain, prepare and eat their food. The Japanese buy in small shops and use chopsticks to eat fish, lotus root and rice. The Mexicans use a market and their own garden and use fingers to eat chicken stew. The Americans use cutlery to eat chicken, corn and salad from a supermarket.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Churchill Films, George McQuilkin, Jane Treiman and James Kennedy

results.title: Families: earning and spending
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, George McQuilkin, Jane Treiman and James Kennedy
results.brief_description: Shows the ways in which the three families introduced in the film “Families: alike and different” earn money and how they spend it on a variety of goods and services. The American parents work at separate jobs, the Mexican family is involved in the processing coffee beans and the Japanese father does research into water pollution.

results.title: Families: alike and different
results.creator_credit: Churchill Films, George McQuilkin, Jane Treiman and James Kennedy
results.brief_description: Compares the daily activities of three families from Japan, Mexico and the United States as told by the children. Shows the settings in which they live: a crowded Tokyo home, the San Francisco hills and the expansive rural three house compound of Yasalon.

results.title: Families get angry
results.creator_credit: Oxford Films (U.S.), John Simons and Delton Cook
results.brief_description: A family quarrel begins when the father in a black, low-income family is trying to stretch too little money to pay too many bills. The two children are strongly affected by their parents’ conflict.

results.title: Families
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Griffith University, Asian Studies Council and Robin James
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Dragons tongue. - Series 2.”.
In this Chinese language program, Professor Colin Mackerras looks at the importance of family in Chinese culture, especially since the law restricted family size to one child in order to contain the population. Chinese Law since the 1950’s forbade polygamy and arranged marriages, and now young people can choose their own partners. The status of women and girls is discussed and the problems encountered raising single children. The program also looks at oracle bones and how these lead to the creation of written language.
results.creator_credit_for_label: ABC-TV (Australia), Griffith University, Asian Studies Council and Robin James

results.title: Familiar places (A)
results.creator_credit: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and David MacDougall
results.brief_description: Shows the recent movement of Aboriginal people back to their traditional lands. As this movement has grown Aborigines have seen the importance of mapping their land, and we see anthropologist Peter Sutton helping them. Peter Sutton provides a commentary on what he has learned about Aboriginal ties to the land.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and David MacDougall

results.title: Famiglia Martini
results.creator_credit: Scopo Media Productions, Rosa Colosimo and Franco Cavarra
results.brief_description: This tape consists of three Italian language programmes aimed at years 7 to 9. 1. “L’Incontro”. The younger members of the Martini famili go to the disco. 2.”Alla saluta”. Mr. Martini is encouraged by members of his family to go on a diet. 3.”La Partita a tennis”. Conflict occurs over who goes to tennis.

results.title: Famicom: Nintendo Family Computer HVC-001
results.material_description: Video game console with game controllers.  Includes original box with transformer, power cord and computer user manual. Object display only and not functioning
results.brief_description: Famicom Nintendo Family Computer HVC-001 video games console unit. Red and white plastic computer unit with two gaming controllers attached by black power cords. Controllers have ports designed to rest them either side of the unit. Console comes in original packaging (box) with RF switch, power cable and manual. The manual is written in foreign language
